prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Shirley.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Jacob, Shirley, Jason, Matthew, Rebecca, Timothy, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Shirley's) goal: Deceive others, avoid detection, and eliminate villagers.

{secret}

prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Jacob.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Jacob, Shirley, Jason, Matthew, Rebecca, Timothy, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Jacob's) goal: Act openly and collaboratively to identify werewolves.

{secret}

Here is the context of the interaction:


Conversation Starts:

Turn #0: [Game] State: Night_werewolf. The game begins!

Turn #1: [Game] Entering state: Night_seer

Turn #2: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #3: [Game] Shirley was killed by werewolves!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #4: Jacob: said: "Shirley has been killed by the werewolves. We need to work together to figure out who the other werewolves are. I'm not sure who exactly is a wolf, but I think we should focus on finding inconsistencies in the players' behavior and trust each other during the discussion."

Turn #5: Jason: said: "Shirley's death is a strong clue — she was killed by the werewolves, so she's definitely not a villager. I think we should look closely at the others. Timothy was inspected by me and is a villager, which makes him safe. I'm still cautious about the others, especially Matthew and Rebecca, who seem to be acting unusually. I suggest we keep an eye on them during the discussion and vote carefully."

Turn #6: Matthew: said: "I think it’s really troubling that Jason is pointing fingers at both Matthew and Rebecca. It’s almost as if he’s trying to deflect attention from himself. Let’s not forget he’s the one that suggested we vote out possibly innocent players. We should consider all perspectives, but I believe Jason is too eager to push suspicion onto us. I suggest we keep a close watch on him."

Turn #7: Rebecca: said: "Jason, I appreciate your input, but I want to clarify something — Timothy was saved by me during the night, which means he is not a werewolf. That makes him a safe player. I also want to emphasize that I have no reason to suspect anyone else, especially not Matthew or Rebecca. I trust the group's collective judgment and believe we should focus on finding consistent behavior and facts, not on personal attacks. Let's keep the discussion fair and constructive."

Turn #8: Timothy: said: "Rebecca, I appreciate your clarification about saving me, but I want to make sure we're all on the same page — I did not receive any save during the night, and I believe the game mechanics state that only the witch can use the save potion. Since I was not saved, and I was not inspected by the seer, I can only confirm that I am not a werewolf based on the information available. I trust the group's discussion and want to emphasize that we should focus on the facts, such as who was killed and who might have been inspected, rather than personal accusations. Let's keep our discussion open, respectful, and based on shared evidence."
